verses.text: I myself also am a mortal man, like to all, and the offspring of him that was first made of the earth,
and in \add my\add* motherâ€™s womb was fashioned \add to be\add* flesh in the time of ten months, being compacted in blood, of the seed of man, and the pleasure that came with sleep.
And when I was born, I drew in the common air, and fell upon the earth, \add which is\add* of like nature, and the first voice which I uttered was crying, as all \add others\add* do.
I was nursed in swaddling clothes, and \add that\add* with cares.
For \add there is\add* no king \add that\add* had any other beginning of birth.
For all \add men\add* have one entrance into life, and the like going out.
Wherefore I prayed, and understanding was given me: I called upon \add God\add*, and the spirit of wisdom came to me.
I preferred her before sceptres and thrones, and esteemed riches nothing in comparison of her.
Neither compared I unto her \add any\add* precious stone, because all gold in respect of her \add is as\add* a little sand, and silver shall be counted as clay before her.
I loved her above health and beauty, and chose to have her instead of light: for the light that \add cometh\add* from her never goeth out.
All good \add things\add* together came to me with her, and innumerable riches in her hands.
And I rejoiced in \add them\add* all, because wisdom goeth before them: and I knew not that she was the mother of them.
I learned diligently, and do communicate \add her\add* liberally: I do not hide her riches.
For she is a treasure unto men that never faileth: which they that use become the friends of God, being commended for the gifts that \add come\add* from learning.
God hath granted me to speak as I would, and to conceive as is meet for the \add things\add* that are given \add me:\add* because it is he that leadeth unto wisdom, and directeth the wise.
For in his hand \add are\add* both we and our words; all wisdom also, and knowledge of workmanship.
For he hath given me certain knowledge of the \add things\add* that are, \add namely\add*, to know how the world was made, and the operation of the elements:
the beginning, ending, and midst of the times: the alterations of the turning \add of the sun\add*, and the change of seasons:
the circuits of years, and the positions of stars:
the natures of living creatures, and the furies of wild beasts: the violence of winds, and the reasonings of men: the diversities of plants, and the virtues of roots:
and all such \add things\add* as are \add either\add* secret or manifest, \add them\add* I know.

For wisdom, \add which is\add* the worker of all \add things\add*, taught me: for in her is an understanding spirit, holy, one only, manifold, subtil, lively, clear, undefiled, plain, not subject to hurt, loving the \add thing that is\add* good, quick, which cannot be letted, ready to do good,
kind to man, stedfast, sure, free from care, having all power, overseeing all things, and going through all understanding, pure, \add and\add* most subtil, spirits.
For wisdom \add is\add* more moving than any motion: she passeth and goeth through all \add things\add* by reason of \add her\add* pureness.
For she is the breath of the power of God, and a pure influence flowing from the glory of the Almighty: therefore can no defiled \add thing\add* fall into her.
For she is the brightness of the everlasting light, the unspotted mirror of the power of God, and the image of his goodness.

And being \add but\add* one, she can do all \add things:\add* and remaining in herself, she maketh all \add things\add* new: and in \add all\add* ages entering into holy souls, she maketh \add them\add* friends of God, and prophets.
For God loveth none but him that dwelleth with wisdom.
For she is more beautiful than the sun, and above all the order of stars: being compared with the light, she is found before \add it\add*.
For after this cometh night: but vice shall not prevail against wisdom.
